header.matter: MURDER OF MR WALTERS, BANK ROBBERY AND ATTEMPTED  HI-JACKING

testimony: Good afternoon.  The Panel is the same as we were constituted this morning.  I'm going to ask the legal representatives to announce themselves for the purpose of the record.
Good afternoon.  My name is Zarina Loonat ...(indistinct).  I'm representing the applicant in this matter today, Mr Musa Mahambane.  Thank you.
Good afternoon Members of the Panel.  I'm Marcia de Klerk.  I'm representing the victim, Mrs Walters, Martin Craven, Mrs ...(indistinct), Mrs ...(indistinct) and Mrs Smith.  Thank you.
Could you just go by those names of the people, of the victims again please?
Mrs Walters who's the next of kin of Derek Walters who is ...
Mr Craven, Martin Craven.  Then Mr de Grubb.  However Miss de Grubb hasn't been included in the indictment, you know, for the trial. He hasn't suffered any injuries.
But is he willing to participate in the process because he can still be regarded as a victim?
Well Mr de Grubb, I have got his instructions to oppose the application for amnesty.
Then there's Mrs Barkor who is present.  Mr Barkor is the wife of Vic Barkor who was shot in the eye outside the NBS, who has subsequently a few months later died.
As a result of his injury?

Well, that hasn't been ascertained as a definite conclusion.  Mr Barkor died of a brain haemorrhage which could have been as a result of the injuries sustained.  Then there's Mrs Catherine Druft.  Mrs Druft has also indicated to me, well given me her instructions to oppose the application.  However, she's unavailable to attend the hearing today on the basis that she underwent an operation on Friday and she's still hospitalised.  And then there's Mrs Gloria Smith.  She said that she's not interested in attending the hearing or anything, but she does oppose the application.
She opposes the application for amnesty.  However, she's not interested in attending the hearing as such.

Now before we carry on, I see you have possibly 6 people who could be regarded as victims, all of whom are opposing the application.  On what basis would they be opposing the application given the requirements of the Act?

The basis of the opposition is the fact that they don't feel that the robbery as such, or the murder of Mr Walters, was politically motivated.  They can't see the political object which the applicant was striving to achieve.  It seems to be common amongst all the victims that this was just a blatant robbery, an attempted hijacking, whereby an innocent person, because he couldn't get loose of a seat belt, was murdered.
	In terms of ...(intervention)
Mr Walters.  In light of that, that the applicant doesn't fulfil the requirements in order for him to succeed in the application for amnesty.

Yes.  Ms de Klerk in the meantime I think it'd be wise for you to get some information where applicable, where people have died, whether there are any children left as well, because they would, in the event of us granting in this case amnesty, they in addition to the surviving spouse, would be regarded as victims.
Yes, Ms Loonat.  Does your client speak Zulu?
Mr Mahambane, you were born on the 29th of March 1966 in Newlands in Durban, you are a South African citizen, is that correct?
You are now 34 years old and you have spent, according to the record, 7 years in prison of your 20 year sentence, is that correct?

The sentence was imposed on you on the 23rd of May 1993, for committing the following offences on the 26th of October 1991, at the NBS, the Natal Building Society, in Umhlanga, namely robbery, attempted murder of Mr Barkor, Messrs Barkor, Reed and Craven and the unlawful possession of firearms and ammunition, is that correct?
In respect of who are the attempted murder application made?
Mr Barkor, Mr Reed and Mr Craven.  Your Honour, this is on page 64 of the bundle, line 20.
Reed and Mr Craven and I get that from the bundle on page 64.
The unlawful possession of firearms and ammunition.
May I proceed Your Honour?  Thank you.  Sir, are you married?
Where do you live?  Where do your children live?
So were you employed prior to this offence?
I used to be a taxi driver.
Do you have any previous convictions?
What political party do you belong to?
Are you a registered member of the ANC?
I am not a card carrying member.
No, at that time it was not very important to have a card
How long were you a supporter of the ANC?
I started supporting the ANC in 1985 after Mrs ...(indistinct) death.
Before we proceed, could you please tell the Panel what your level of education was at the time?
So it was after standard 9 that you got involved in politics, is that correct?
I was saying so, but we also used to have political meeting at school.
Are you trained to use one?
We received very basic training on how to use a firearm.
He is the person who used to issue out instructions when we held meetings.
At the time, we were under constant attack from Lindelane residents and the police, so we were involved in defending our community.
What type of instructions did he give?
As to strategising as to how to best defend ourselves against these attacks.
And he taught you how to use a firearm?
Yes, he was the person who demonstrated to us.
How many lessons did you have?
It was not very thorough, but he just showed us the firearm and ...(intervention)
How many lessons did you have?
How many students were there when you were trained on these two occasions?
So he would do at least, or most, 10 at a time?
Yes, we'd never be more than 10.
What kind of gun or firearm were you trained in?
It was a 9mm and a pump gun.
Was that at the same lesson or on different lessons?
He first brought the pump gun and then subsequently he brought smaller firearms.
And each of the students would be trained in a gun?
Now how did it come you were part of this training session?
How did it come that you were part of the training programme?
I was a little bit older than my colleagues.
I'm saying, he had faith in me.
Maybe you misunderstand the question.  How did it come that you were told to go to this training session?

I realised the severity of the situation in the area at that time and decided that one should receive training.
...(END OF TAPE) on how to use a firearm.
To defend ourselves, so that we would be in a position to fight the attackers.
When you got the training, were you employed at that time?
Were you not looking for work at the time?
How long did these sessions take?
It would be less than an hour.
Can I just ask something Chair, while you're at it?  When did these training sessions take place?  What year?
I do not recall precisely, but this happened after 1985, around 86, 87.
Thank you.  Sir, you say Mandla was the person who taught you the use of firearms.  How did he become a leader in your eyes?

Mandla used to reside in G Section but he was requested by the people from L Section to come reside in our area, so that he could help to protect the community and he was also the person who used to liaise with people in senior positions.
He's a school principal and he is the person who fetched Mandla from G Section and let him stay at his home for the purpose of helping in the protection of the community.
So you say that Mandla was brought from G Section to L Section to assist you all with training and things to do with the ANC party, is that correct?
He was brought from G Section to K Section.
Is that where you resided, K Section?
Please tell the members of the Panel what got you interested in politics?

Sorry, can I just clarify something.  Sorry to interrupt.  You said earlier that he was requested by the people of L Section to come and live in your area, now you're saying he lived in K Section.  What Section did you live in?
Bheki Manzi brought Mandla from G Section and let him stay in his house in K Section and he was there to assist in protecting the community.  I resided at L Section.

Your evidence was and I've got a note here, that he used to reside in G Section, he was requested by the people of L Section and he came to live in our area to protect the community.  Then you were asked about Bheki Manzi and you said Manzi went and fetched him from G Section.
Just clarify it for us please.
Where was he staying?  Where were you staying?
Mandla used to reside at G Section.  Bheki Manzi fetched him to stay at his home so that he could assist.  I resided at L Section.
So what section was he assisting to defend?
So how did you come to be involved in protecting K Section?
We were protecting our Section, L Section, not K, it's Mandla who was brought to K Section.
Anyway you can clear it up in due course.
Mr Mahambane, please tell the Honourable Members of this Panel what got you interested in politics from your school days?  What events led up to your interest, your active participation in politics?
Firstly it was the death of Mrs ...(indistinct). After that incident all shops were burned down in the township.
When was he killed?  Was it Victoria?  When was Victoria killed?
In 1987, her boy, who was my neighbour, Sikumbuso Ndlovo, as killed in Lindelane.  The people who killed him who were Mr Tshabalala's men, were arrested but later released.
He was a leader in Lindelane.
And this is when you witnessed the death of your friends, is that correct?
There were seven of them who were found dead in Lindelane and one of them was my neighbour, Sikumbuso Ndlovo.
Mr Mahambane, now you got interested in politics, in 1985 you joined the ANC, correct?
And I assume that that was after Victoria Ntenye was killed.
You were not a comrade before then?
Everyone in the township was a comrade.
We were all comrades in the township.
Well then maybe you understand comrades not the way I do. And you learned to use a firearm in 1986/87 you say?
As a comrade, under which banner did you, or let me put it this way, were you politically active?
Did you do anything under a political banner?
We would hold meetings at the township.
Is that all?  You'd only have meetings?
We also used to guard over the township at night.
We used to discuss means of securing funds to be able to buy ammunition and firearms to defend ourselves.
Yes and what were the means discussed and decided upon of acquiring funds?
I would inquire from Mandla if the organisation had no funds available and he said there were none, so we were supposed to take our own initiative on how to secure funds.
At the time, we used to hold discussions on the issue, but no decision would be taken.
But surely some ideas must have been raised at that meeting.
What used to happen was when funds were available, people used to use them to go into exile.

Maybe you don't understand the question, I'm going to put it one more time.  You say in the meetings you used to discuss funding of the organisation.  Now what was suggested there in those meetings regarding the accumulation of funds?  How would you people be able to get funds?
There were many ideas put forth, for example the stealing of vehicles.
Yes and these meetings were being conducted since about 1985 you say, when you joined the organisation?

For how long did these meetings take place where ways and means of getting funds were discussed?  I'm not asking how long each meeting lasted, I'm saying these meetings were held over a period, which, can you give us an idea as to what that period was?
Our meetings would not last long because we could not arrive at a decision.
Now did such meetings - such meetings were held in 1985, correct?
When did these, as far as you're concerned, when did these meetings stop?
Some comrades fled into exile during that course of time, but they lasted up until 1990's.
So every year from 1985 to 1990, you attended various meetings regarding the accumulation of funds, am I correct?  Do I understand you correctly?

It was not only the question of funds that was discussed at those meetings, there were other issues that were raised.  I just regret the fact that I'm addressing people who do not know what type of life we led at the township at that time.

Let me rest you assured that each and every one of us are aware of what type of life was lived in South Africa.  Apart from that, the quality of life we lived, different people, has nothing to do with the question.  All I'm asking is as far as you're concerned, when did you stop attending such meetings?
We used to attend those meetings even in 1990, 1991.
Now you can remember the only method of accumulating funds that you remember, you say, was stealing vehicles.  That was one of the suggestions, correct?
It was not only that, but there was also a suggestion for every person to contribute something towards that fund.
Now were you told now what to do with this, or how was this car going to help your treasury?
There are people who buy stolen cars in the township.
Yes, but that's not the question.  Who would see it, not who would buy it.  Who would sell it?
I could have sold it because I know of certain people in the township.

I see, that's what I was getting at.  What I'm trying to find out is once a car is stolen, what would be done with that car?  Would the thief go sell it or would you be expected to hand it in to certain official of the organisation for him to sell it? What would be the position?
We would have approach Mandla about the latter and he would have to decide how to dispose of the car.
I ask that question because we've heard this type of evidence before, but yet you tell me you could have sold it.  What is the correct position?
The primary issue was getting the funds, it was not so important who sold the vehicle.  We could have sold it on our own and brought the money back to Mandla.

Wasn't it the rule that once you stole a car, you should go to your Commander and say:  "Look, we have succeeded in stealing a car.  We have it.  What must we do now with it?"  Wasn't that the practice?
Unfortunately no vehicle was stolen, but it was an idea that was raised at a meeting.

So in the five or six years that you were involved in these meetings where amongst other things ideas as to how to raise funds, including the theft of vehicles, you were not party to such an event, am I correct?
There were many things that took place.
Can you just repeat that, Ms Interpreter?
The applicant said there were many things that took place at the time.
Didn't he also say he couldn't remember as a result?
Some of which he could not remember.
I have been in prison for a while, so I do not know whether he's still alive.

Your Honour, may I add to that please?  This matter was set down last year and because it was remanded for this year at that time because we couldn't get hold of Mandla, the investigation wasn't properly done.  At the time we were in Pietermaritzburg and Lulama Mtanga was the Evidence Leader and whilst we were there in Pietermaritzburg, she phoned a telephone number that my client had given her.  It  was the neighbour of Mandla, and that is when she realised that there was such a person, when the person at the other end answered and so this is why we remanded for this year, because there was some truth in what he was saying.  It was a gentleman, or somebody called Kholane, who answered and said:  "Yes, Mandla does live next door" and this was when the matter was remanded for this year because investigations weren't complete and I believe it's still not been followed up.  I personally tried to phone this number when I was given instruction again this year and the number's dead.  The number that was given then is 503 5077 and that is what I believe Ms Mtanga dialled while we were there, so there was an existence of such a person.  Thank you.

So you tell us that over a period of 5 to 6 years, you cannot recollect whether there was a motor car theft, do I understand you correctly?  Am I correct?  There was never a car theft during that five or six years that you were attending these meetings?
Was there any other idea, or other way of raising funds for the organisation that was in fact put into operation?
Will you please repeat the question?
You say that there was never a car theft during that period.  Did the organisation or was the organisation able to raise funds in any other way during that period?
There was a time when comrades collected or contributed towards assisting others to cross into exile, but that was not much.
But that had nothing to do with the collecting of money for firearms, that was for a different purpose, correct?
It was not much, so it could not have bought firearms.  We just gave it to the comrades who were going into exile.
So the only reason - the only manner collecting money that you know of that was discussed at all these meetings, was the stealing of vehicles?  Do we understand you correctly?
No, that is not so.  We also managed to contribute or to collect some monies amongst ourselves, but it was not enough.
And besides that, was there any other manner of collecting money, besides the two you have now mentioned?
Eventually Mandla realised that the issue of collecting funds was not progressing, so it was decided that we should go rob a bank.
When did that happen, or when was that decided?
Was it in one of these meetings?
Because he trusted me, Mandla called me aside.
Was it at one of these meetings?
It was after the meeting that he approached me.
Did he approach you privately, or in front of others?
He just called me to the side.

Then he told me that because of our failure to secure funds in any other manner, he realises that we would have to rob a bank and there was one bank that he knew of.  He also instructed me to get two other people to assist in that mission.
Did I hear you correctly, he told you which bank to go to?
And you say this instruction came in 1990?
More or less in which month?
It was towards the end of the year.
Can I just check something, if I may.  Did he also say to you that you should get two others to help you?  Did I hear that properly?
He said because he could not identify anybody he trusted in the meeting, I should look two other people who would assist me.
So he didn't know of any other comrades to help you with this, therefore he told you to find two other people.  Is that right?
Yes, I think so, that's how we saw it.
Well did he tell you that or didn't he?
The comrades were busy at K Section, so they could not have assisted us.

But you told us a few seconds ago that it was because he didn't have anyone he trusted.  You told us a few seconds ago, you told us that he didn't have anyone that he trusted therefore you should look for someone else.  Do you understand the question?

I said to you, I was trying to clarify whether he had told you to find other people or not and you said yes, there was no-one else that he trusted at the meeting, no other comrades that he trusted that were present there and therefore you should find other people.
Yes, I was supposed to look for two other persons.
Yes.  The issue here is the reason why you should go and look for other people.  You don't understand what I'm saying to you?
I would not be able to say or state the reason with certainty because he was the one who told me to go and look for other persons.
Why would you answer like that if you're not sure?  You were asked, how did it come that he asked you and you said he didn't trust other people in the meeting.

Then take my word for it, that was your answer.  That he asked you, Mandla called you aside and told you that you should go rob a bank and you should go find assistance with two other people and he did so because he didn't trust anybody else in the meeting, but you.
So it wasn't a question that there were comrades that were busy at K Section and therefore they couldn't help you?
Those comrades were from K Section, we resided at L.
Mr Mahambane, you have us understand that it was Mandla who instructed you to rob the bank in Umhlanga, is that correct?
You had two co-accused with you.  Who chose the two co-accused to assist you that day?
Why did not Mandla chose them to help you?
He said because I was going to be responsible for that job, I should decide on who to take with.
Were the two accused, members of the ANC party as well?
Why did you chose two criminals to assist you in what was a politically motivated attack?
I knew that they were criminals who were always after money.  I knew that it would not be easy for them to refuse.
To refuse the attraction of robbing a bank?
They would not have refused to rob a bank because they were criminals who used to.
Yes, I know of a few others who love money too.  Now tell me, when you approached these two people, what was the arrangement you had with them?
I informed them that there was a bank we were to rob.  I informed them that there was a bank that we were supposed to rob and they said they wanted to go see it.
Tell us that whole story now.  One of the things you must do to get amnesty, you must tell us everything.  I want to know how you approached these people, how did you persuade them to participate?

As I knew that they were criminals who were attracted to money, I was convinced that they would not refuse to accompany me, so when I arrived I told them that there was a job to do and they asked:  "What?"  I said it was a bank to rob and they wanted to go see the bank and we went.
But how did you know these people?
They resided in the township and there aren't that many people.  You know your fellow residents.
So they weren't friends of yours, they were just people you knew?
Yes, I knew them from afar, they were not my friends.
So they were really strangers to you, just people you knew that lived in the township and you knew that they were criminals.
I would not call them strangers because we would sometimes meet at the soccer ground or wherever in the township.
In any case, you were supposed to be the main person in control, the Commander of this group to go rob a bank, correct?
What did you tell them why this job must be done?  Did you tell them that?
I did not give them any reasons.  They would not have accepted my reasons, that it was for political reasons, because these were criminals.

Did you tell them that:  "Look here ..."  How did you propose to then share the money?  This job -this robbery of this bank was supposed to be done and committed for the benefit of your organisation totally.  How were you planning to get away with 100% of what you robbed that bank of and give it to Mandla or whoever, because here you had two accomplices who were criminals and lots of money?  How were you going to overcome that?
Before we left for that mission, we actually left from Mandla's home and we had planned that we would return there.

And, were they not told:  "Look, when we go on this robbery, this is not a normal robbery like happened in the old days in Texas where we share the money.  All this money we take, we're going to give it to the organisation", did you not tell them that?
No, they would have refused, had I told them so.
How were you going then to overcome this problem when they said:  "Look, we want our share of the money.  We're going to split it three ways."
That would have been decided on our return.

I want you to think about that.  We're going to adjourn for five minutes.
COMMITTEE ADJOURNS
ON RESUMPTION

Your Honour, may I have permission first to address one matter that arose early in the evidence when I questioned my client about a previous conviction.  At the time he denied it, but it's been worrying him because he did admit it to me and it seemed to have escaped my mind. He did have a previous conviction for stealing a purse, for which he got 4 strokes, he was 19 years old and he just wanted to clarify that before he proceeds.
Okay.  Would you like me to question?  Thank you.

(cont.)
	Mr Mahambane, you and your co-accused were instructed by Mandla to attack the bank and you left from Mandla's house at the time.  The question is, when you obtained - if your robbery was a success, how were you going to convince two criminals who were not ANC supporters or members to hand over the money to Mandla?

I trusted that Mandla and Bheki Manzi would be able to convince these two persons to hand over the money.  I was the person, the primary person in that operation.  I had the cash when we left the bank and from there we were going to go straight to Mandla's home.
Just clarify something.  So Bheki Manzi knew about this plan as well?
Well then how would he convince them if he didn't know about it?
There is a person from whom Mandla received his instructions, I assumed that they would be able to convince these two persons between themselves.
Surely if he was going to convince them, he would have to know about the plan?  He would have to know what they had done, to convince them to part with the money, surely?
With regards to Bheki Manzi, I am just assuming that he should have assisted but the person who was close to me and whom I dealt with directly, was Mandla.

What makes things worse is that you took these two crooks to Mandla's house and you three leave from Mandla's house on this escapade of yours and yet you don't discuss it with Mandla as to:  "Look here, I'm going to bring them back here with the money, you better see to it that you are able to convince them to part with the money", you just assume that Mandla and somebody else is going to be able to do so.  How's that?
I hoped that they would understand our mission because they were also aware of the circumstances under which we lived in the township.
So are you saying, they would understand that you were on a mission for the ANC?
Even if it was not an ANC mission per se, but it was directed at defending our community, because the primary objective was to be able to buy ammunition.
Now tell me something, this crime was committed in 1991 October, correct?
The ANC was unbanned in February 1990, correct?
By October 1991, Umkhonto weSizwe was fully operational within the country, do you recall that?
Yes, but at that time attacks on the townships had not stopped.  We were still being attacked by the KwaZulu police.
Let me finish.  Do you recall that Umkhonto weSizwe was operative in the country then?  Correct?
And by then the ANC or MK had already structured self-defence units, correct?  Do you recall that?
They were not formed in the township.
Yes, I am because there were still no-go areas in L Section.

That's precisely the point.  No-go areas was a phenomenon that arose with the advent of self-defence units.  Before the self-defence units came into operation, those that were causing strife had a free hand in the Council and when the SDU came about, that is when people said:  "Look, there's no go areas and this is our area, that is your area.  Let's keep apart and try to keep peace."  Do you recall that?  That's how it used to work, isn't it?
I recall that, but I do not remember any SDUs at L Section, KwaMashu.
But you recall that, as I put it to you?
I do recall and I used to hear about the establishment of SDUs, but it did not happen in our township.

You see why I'm raising that with you is that the SDUs, because you say Mandla was attached to through the ANC and the MK connections, the SDUs were being provided with firearms largely at that early stage.  It's only long after that, well not so long, the period after that they found it necessary to embark on their own fund raising methods to obtain further ammunition and firearms, but not at that early stage.  That's why I'm raising the issue of the SDU with you.  Do you follow what I'm saying?
Now can you deal with that please.
We did not receive any assistance from the organisation in terms of firearms.
Was Mandla linked to any SDUs as far as you know?
No, I don't recall.  I don't even understand the nature of the SDU's role, because it was something that I just heard about.
Mr Mahambane, all of you were armed on that particular day, is that correct?
Where did you obtain these firearms?
Did you intend to use these loaded firearms that day?
It was not our intention to go and kill anyone on that day, we just wanted to get the money.
Why was it necessary to come forward then?
It was to be used as a threat so that they would hand over the money, because we did not shoot anyone at the bank.
One firearm would have done that.  Is that not so?  If it was to be used as a scare mechanism, then whether you have one gun or three guns, you'll have the same result, not so?
I do not see how my accomplices would have agreed to go there unarmed.
That is so.  When robbers go to a bank, they expect resistance, is that not so?

And isn't that the reason why you people armed yourselves, to overcome the expected resistance?  You know that at that time already banks were being guarded at the front door and in the bank by private guards, not so?

Before we carried out the robbery, we went to survey the area and we did find out that there was no-one who guarded the bank and the staff inside the bank were all female.  We thought that it was going to be easy to go in there and get the money.

I'll ask the question again.  If it was going to be that easy, why take the guns?  You knew that there could be resistance, is that not so, and all three of you were going to use your firearms if that resistance materialised.  Correct?
We did not know that there was going to be resistance, we just thought that we would just go in there, take the money and leave.
That only happened in Alice in Wonderland.  You must have known that there was going to be resistance, you expected you, all robbers expect it.  Now tell me, did all three of you go into the bank?
I was in front because I carried the shotgun.  Two of us went in and one remained outside.
And how did you get there?
The driver fled once we were inside the bank.
Four of you went to the bank.  One was driving, one guarded outside the bank and two of you went inside?
Now where did Themba come from?  It's the first time we're hearing about Themba now.
Themba was the driver of the vehicle.  He fled.  He could not even be found.
Ja, you've already told us he fled, but who asked him to drive the car, or who asked him to participate in this robbery?
Was he also one of these crooks?
After I had approached these two persons, I realised that we needed a driver.
So you were going to have to overcome the problem of three other people wanting their share of the booty, not so?
So you were going to go on this escapade on behalf of a political party to rob a bank for what could easily be only a quarter of the booty, correct?
The primary aim was to obtain money to buy firearms.
Have you got any more questions Ms Loonat?

Yes, Your Honour.  Mr Mahambane, there are affidavits in the record which is submitted by your two co-accused, denying any knowledge of the political motive of the robbery.  Please will you comment on that.
Yes, that is so, because I did not disclose to them the objectives of robbing the bank.
Mr Mahambane, please tell us what happened, how did it come about that Mr Walters was killed on that day?

Because the driver of the car had already fled when we got out of the bank, we realised that we did not have transport, so we had to look for a get-away car.  Accused number 3 went to the driver's side and I went to the passenger's side.  Mr Walters tried to unfasten his seat belt and because of the commotion at that time, my co-accused got a fright and fired at Mr Walters.
Did you fire any shots on that day?
I do not recall firing any shots.  When I was running away, I had the firearm pointed upwards all the time.
May I just ask a question, if I may.  Mr Mahambane, in the judgment the Judge talks about, you were carrying the pump gun weren't you, it was a shot gun?

But that talks of several shot gun cartridges being picked up at the scene of the crime in the Judgment.  If you like I'll find it for you and your lawyer can canvass it with you, but you can take my word for it.
Was anyone else armed with a shot gun?
As far as I can recall, I am the only person who had a shotgun.
Yes.  And as far as you recall, you didn't fire it?

For the record, I did canvass the one shot that was fired, because I explained to my client that he did say that although he can't remember clearly, one shot did go off and he hurt himself with it accidentally, but he did not shoot at anybody at any time.  Thank you.  On page 45 of the bundle, line 10 it confirms that there was the unfired rounds in the magazine and one fired round in the chamber, for the record.
	So you did not form the intention at any time to kill or even shoot at anyone, is that correct?
No, I did not have any such intentions because even before we left, I did explain to my accomplices that we are not going out there to kill, but to obtain the money.
